episodes.natural_language:
This matter concerns client Julmonzhae Moore in a motor vehicle accident that occurred on August 29, 2023, currently filed as Julmonzhae-Moore-MVA-8-29-2023 with TM number 23-24627. On September 5, 2023, Whaley Law Firm attorney Jessa Galosmo sent an email regarding Ms. Moore’s August 29 accident to Jennifer Orstrom (Legal Subrogation) at TeamCare – A Central States Health Fund, with a copy to a Filevine contact. The message, dated September 5, 2023 at 14:56:47 −0400, stated three requested items: the type of accident, all relevant insurance information with company names and claim or policy numbers, and a copy of the police report if applicable. Jessa indicated that she had attached a copy of the police report.

In the email, Jessa specified that the accident type was a motor vehicle accident. She provided the following insurance information: a PIP claim with Liberty Mutual, policy number 054658453-03; and a bodily injury claim with Elco Insurance, with the claim number still in process. She noted that a copy of the police report was attached and thanked the recipient.

Jennifer Orstrom, Senior Subrogation Investigation Specialist in TeamCare’s Legal Subrogation Department, replied on the same day, September 5, 2023, at approximately 12:07 PM. She acknowledged receipt of the letter of representation for Ms. Moore’s August 29 accident and requested that, if possible, the following information be provided: (1) the type of accident; (2) all relevant insurance information (company names and claim/policy numbers); and (3) a copy of the police report, if applicable. Her message included her title and contact information: TeamCare – A Central States Health Fund, 8647 W. Higgins Road, Chicago, IL 60631; office phone (847) 939-2246; fax (847) 518-9718; email jorstrom@centralstatesfunds.org. The transmission also contained attorney-privilege/confidentiality language and a disclaimer stating that only the Board of Trustees may interpret the benefits plans, that representations about benefits are estimates or projections and not guarantees, and that all benefits will be paid in accordance with the applicable plan documents.

All the best, Jessa Galosmo, Whaley Law Firm. Ph: (502)357-9975; Fax: (502)364-9363.
episodes.author: Jessa

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Julmonzhae-Moore-MVA-8-29-2023. The client is Julmonzhae Moore. The case concerns a motor vehicle accident that occurred on August 29, 2023, involving Dewayne Ward, Julmonzhae Moore, Daquan Graham, and Ashlee Williams. Bodily injury liability (BI) was denied.

On September 14, 2023, a forwarded email labeled “Fwd: 14-55R0-02D” was sent from Jessa Galosmo of the Whaley Law Firm to colleagues at Whaley Law Firm: Aaron Whaley, Bryce Koon, and Justin Chumbley. The forwarded message notes the MVA occurred on August 29, 2023 and states that BI liability was denied.

Earlier that same day, September 14, 2023, a separate email from HOME CLMS-STATEFARMCLAIMS was received with the subject line “14-55R0-02D.” The To line shows jessa@whaleylawfirm.com and a reference to statefarm.com?. The body instructs the recipient to open the attached documents for more claim information or next steps. It includes a caution not to include sensitive personal information—such as Social Security numbers, credit or debit card numbers, driver’s license numbers, or health/medical information—in email communications. If such information must be transmitted to State Farm, it advises contacting the claim associate to request a secure email channel.

The message also promotes obtaining the claim contact card via text by sending AUTO to 62789 or HOME to 62789, or by downloading the card on a mobile device. The message is signed by Aaron Lovato, State Farm Injury Claims Specialist, with a work phone number of (970) 395-4331.

The note ends with the Whaley Law Firm contact details: Jessa Galosmo’s signature, including the firm’s name and phone and fax numbers—Ph: (502) 357-9975 and Fax: (502) 364-9363—followed by “All the best.”
episodes.author: Jessa

In the forwarded note, Jessa wrote: “Hi Atty. Whaley, Bills from Starlight Chiropractic went over $6,000. Can we release reservations to continue payment to Starlight?”

The forwarded thread included a message from Lisa Rivera, a Claim Resolution Specialist NF II with USRM Medical Claims, dated October 11, 2023 at 12:35? PM, labeled “Julmonzhae Moore 054658453-03.” Rivera addressed Jessa and stated: “Hello Jessa, Please send updated Direction to pay and let me know if I need to stop pay the check since payments over $6,000.” Rivera signed as:

Lisa Rivera  
Claim Resolution Specialist NF II  
USRM Medical Claims

Her contact information and mailing options were provided as follows:

- USPS Mail Only: Liberty Mutual or Safeco Claims, PO Box 5014, Scranton, PA 18505-5014

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Julmonzhae-Moore-MVA-8-29-2023 involves client Julmonzhae Moore and concerns medical billing related to the motor vehicle accident on August 29, 2023.

In an email thread dated October 11, 2023, discussions centered on the bills from Starlight Chiropractic, which had exceeded $6,000. Jessa Galosmo at Whaley Law Firm asked Atty. Whaley if they could release reservations to continue payment to Starlight. Specifically, she asked, “Hi Atty. Whaley, Bills from Starlight Chiropractic went over $6000. Can we release reservations to continue payment to Starlight?” Later that same day, at 12:43:14 PM, Aaron Whaley responded, “No, we have too many other bills.”

Earlier in the thread, Lisa Rivera, a Claim Resolution Specialist NF II with USRM Medical Claims, forwarded a message to Jessa stating, “Hello Jessa, Please send updated Direction to pay and let me know if I need to stop pay the check since payments over $6,000.” Rivera signed off with her name and title, and provided extensive contact details for Liberty Mutual or Safeco Claims, including mailing and street addresses, direct dial, toll-free numbers, and fax. The USPS Mail Only address listed was Liberty Mutual or Safeco Claims, PO Box 5014, Scranton, PA 18505-5014, and the FedEx/UPS address was Liberty Mutual or Safeco Claims, 19 Bret Collins Drive, Throop, PA 18512. Her direct dial was 856-355-7644, with a toll-free line of 800-2Claims, and a fax number of 888-268-8840. Business hours were listed as Monday to Friday, 7:00 AM to 3:30 PM EST. Rivera also included guidance for Medical Provider Billing Support: phone 855-677-2891, email LibertyPCC@mitchell.com, and directions to submit bills to imaging@libertymutual.com or to the PO Box 5014 Scranton, PA 18505-5014. Rivera concluded with a note about a new capability: “Great news!!! You can now chat with me for claim updates via 2 way text message. Click here to send me an email to opt in. Please include your claim number and the best number to reach you via text.” She also included a reminder to review Liberty Mutual’s privacy policy at www.libertymutual.com/privacy and to file claims online for faster processing at LibertyMutual.com/online-claims or Safeco.com/online-claims.

The thread closes with Jessa Galosmo signing off as part of the Whaley Law Firm, with the contact details: Ph: (502)357-9975 and Fax: (502)364-9363. The final portion of the visible chain shows Aaron Whaley’s signature as well, listing the Whaley Law Firm at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with phone number 502-583-4022.

Case: Julmonzhae-Moore-MVA-8-29-2023. Client: Julmonzhae Moore. This file concerns the matter titled “Re: Julmonzhae Moore 054658453-03.” The exchange began with an email from Jessa Galosmo at Whaley Law Firm to Aaron Whaley, cc’ing Julmonzhae Moore, dated October 11, 2023, at 12:52:56 PM Eastern Time. In that message, Jessa asked whether the current bill released for payment, which had gone over ten dollars, was permissible to pay or whether they should instruct the payer to stop payment because payments were appearing to exceed six thousand dollars.

Earlier, at approximately 12:43 PM on the same day, Aaron Whaley replied, “No, we have too many other bills.” In a follow-up sent around 12:40 PM, Jessa wrote: “Hi Atty. Whaley, Bills from Starlight Chiropractic went over $6,000. Can we release reservations to continue payment to Starlight?”

The thread then includes a forwarded message from Lisa Rivera, a Claim Resolution Specialist NF II with USRM Medical Claims, dated October 11, 2023 at 12:35 PM, addressed to Jessa Galosmo. episodes.natural_language:
In the Julmonzhae-Moore-MVA-8-29-2023 case for client Julmonzhae Moore, the Whaley Law Firm team exchanged emails on October 11, 2023 regarding payment directions for medical bills related to the Julmonzhae Moore file (054658453-03). The first line of note shows a directive from Aaron Whaley: “stop paying if the payment is against our original direction.”

Over the course of the afternoon, Jessa Galosmo sent several replies and questions. Around 12:40 PM, Jessa wrote: “Hi Atty. Whaley, Bills from Starlight Chiropractic went over $6000. Can we release reservations to continue payment to Starlight?” Later, at about 12:43 PM, Aaron responded: “No, we have too many other bills.” Then, at roughly 12:53 PM, Jessa followed up: “The current bill they released for payment went over $10. Is it okay? or should we instruct them to stop pay the check since payments over $6,000.” The chain shows a final entry from Aaron at about 1:02 PM reiterating the initial instruction: “stop paying if the payment is against our original direction.”

Earlier in the thread, there was a forward from Lisa Rivera dated around 12:35 PM. Rivera, identified as a Claim Resolution Specialist NF II with USRM Medical Claims, wrote to Jessa: “Hello Jessa, Please send updated Direction to pay and let me know if I need to stop pay the check since payments over $6,000.” The forwarded message also included Rivera’s signature block with full contact details for Liberty Mutual or Safeco Claims, including mailing and shipping addresses (USPS Mail Only: Liberty Mutual or Safeco Claims, PO Box 5014, Scranton, PA 18505-5014; FedEx/UPS: Liberty Mutual or Safeco Claims, 19 Bret Collins Drive, Throop, PA 18512), direct dial and toll-free numbers, and a fax number, along with business hours (Monday to Friday, 7:00 AM to 3:30 PM EST). Rivera’s message also provided medical provider billing support contact information (Phone: 855-677-2891; Email: LibertyPCC@mitchell.com) and the submission email/address for bills (imaging@libertymutual.com or PO Box 5014 Scranton, PA 18505-5014). The message also promoted two-way text claim updates and suggested submitting claims online for faster processing, with privacy policy and online-claims guidance included.

In their closing lines, the messages from Jessa and Aaron included the standard firm signatures, with Jessa listing Whaley Law Firm contact details (Ph: 502-357-9975; Fax: 502-364-9363) and Aaron noting his address (Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222; 502-583-4022).

In summary, the file shows an ongoing internal discussion about payment directions for medical bills tied to Julmonzhae Moore’s MVA, with a focus on whether to halt payments when bills exceeded certain thresholds (notably $6,000), and a request from Lisa Rivera to update the payment directions and confirm if a stop-payment is required when payments surpass $6,000. The exchange also contains the usual administrative details and contact information related to Liberty Mutual/Safeco Claims and the Whaley Law Firm’s correspondence.

The case file includes an email chain dated October 11, 2023, involving Jessa Galosmo of Whaley Law Firm and Aaron Whaley, with Julmonzhae Moore and related parties copied. The initial response from Jessa, sent at 14:14:25 in the afternoon, simply stated “Got it.”

The discussion on that day centers on whether to continue paying bills tied to the medical-claims directive. At approximately 1:02 PM, Aaron Whaley wrote: “stop paying if the payment is against our original direction.” Earlier, at 12:53 PM, Jessa asked whether the current bill released for payment, which had exceeded $10, was permissible or whether they should instruct the payee to stop payment on the check because payments over $6,000 were at issue. At 12:43 PM, Aaron responded: “No, we have too many other bills.” Then, at 12:40 PM, Jessa queried: “Hi Atty. Whaley, Bills from Starlight Chiropractic went over $6000. Can we release reservations to continue payment to Starlight?”

The thread includes a forwarded message from Lisa Rivera dated October 11, 2023 at 12:35 PM, with the subject “Julmonzhae Moore 054658453-03.” In that message, Lisa Rivera, a Claim Resolution Specialist NF II with USRM Medical Claims, asked Jessa to “Please send updated Direction to pay and let me know if I need to stop pay the check since payments over $6,000.” Rivera also provided extensive contact information for Liberty Mutual or Safeco Claims, including postal and FedEx/UPS addresses, direct dial, toll-free numbers, a fax number, and business hours. The USPS Mail address was Liberty Mutual or Safeco Claims, PO Box 5014, Scranton, PA 18505-5014, and the FedEx/UPS address was Liberty Mutual or Safeco Claims, 19 Bret Collins Drive, Throop, PA 18512. Direct Dial: 856-355-7644; Toll Free: 800-2Claims; Fax: 888-268-8840; Business Hours: Monday to Friday 7:00 AM to 3:30 PM EST. Medical Provider Billing Support could be reached at 855-677-2891, with email LibertyPCC@mitchell.com, and bills could be submitted to imaging@libertymutual.com or to PO Box 5014 Scranton, PA 18505-5014. Rivera added a note promoting two-way text updates: “Great news!!! You can now chat with me for claim updates via 2 way text message. Click here to send me an email to opt in. Please include your claim number and the best number to reach you via text.” She also referenced Liberty Mutual’s privacy policy at www.libertymutual.com/privacy and encouraged faster processing by filing new claims online at Liberty Mutual or Safeco and managing claims at LibertyMutual.com/online-claims or Safeco.com/online-claims.

In closing, the exchange included sign-offs from Jessa Galosmo of Whaley Law Firm, including her phone and fax numbers (Ph: 502-357-9975; Fax: 502-364-9363), followed by a signature block for Aaron Whaley with the Whaley Law Firm address (712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222) and phone number (502-583-4022). The forwarded message was originally sent from HOME CLMS-STATEFARMCLAIMS and dated Friday, November 3, 2023 at 6:45?PM, with the subject line 14-55R0-02D and addressed to jessa@whaleylawfirm.com. The message included the line "statefarm.com?" and instructed the recipient to open the attachment(s) for more claim information or next steps.

For security, the message stated: “For your protection, please do not include sensitive personal information such as Social Security Number, credit/debit card number (financial account number), driver’s license number, or health/medical information in an email. If you must send this type of information to State Farm, please contact your claim associate to request a secure email channel.”

Additionally, the message urged recipients not to miss a call about their Auto claim or Homeowners claim from State Farm, offering two text options: “Text AUTO to 62789 for your claim contact card or download it from your mobile device,” and “Text HOME to 62789 for your claim contact card or download it from your mobile device.”

The message carried the byline of Aaron Lovato, State Farm Injury Claims Specialist. It concluded with a closing from the Whaley Law Firm: “All the best, Jessa Galosmo,” followed by the firm’s contact details: Ph: (502)357-9975 and Fax: (502)364-9363.

The forwarded message contains a prior email from Ebon Moore, dated December 21, 2023 at 4:36 PM (noted in the thread as “4:36?PM”). In that message, Ebon wrote to Jessa: “I am working on the file for your clients Dewayne Ward, Julmonzhae Moore, Ashley Williams and Duquan Graham for the possible Underinsured Injury exposure. After review this file and the available information, I do not perceive an underinsured exposure for these parties. I will be closing this claim at this time. If you have additional information, please bring it to my attention for review.” Ebon I. Moore signed as Sr. Claims Resolution Specialist I, Casualty, Personal Lines.

The message includes the following contact and mailing details for Ebon Moore: USPS Mail (no FedEx or UPS): P.O. Box 5014, Scranton, PA 18505-5014; Direct Phone: 317-805-2834; Fax: 888-268-8840; Business Hours: Monday to Friday (7:30 AM to 4:00 PM EST); USPS Mail Only; FedEx/UPS deliveries: Liberty Mutual or Safeco Claims, P.O. Box 5014, Scranton, PA 18505-5014; Liberty Mutual or Safeco Claims, 19 Bert Collins Drive, Throop, PA 18512. The e-mail also carries the standard confidentiality and privilege notice, stating that the e-mail and attachments are intended only for the named addressees and may contain privileged or confidential information; if received in error, recipients are to notify the sender and permanently delete the message and attachments. The notice is followed by metadata indicating Claim-Number 054717144, Exposure-Number 03, Category Manual Outbound E-Mail, Description undefined, and Template-Id BIFREEFORM.

The message notes that the policy is underwritten by Liberty Mutual Personal Insurance Company. The message concludes with the standard closing from Jessa Galosmo at Whaley Law Firm, including her phone and fax numbers: Ph: (502) 357-9975; Fax: (502) 364-9363. The forwarded thread ends with “All the best, Jessa Galosmo” and her signature block.

In summary, on December 21, 2023, a forwarding email indicated the date of loss as August 29, 2023, and the claim number 054717144-03, involving Dewayne Ward, Julmonzhae Moore, Ashley Williams, and Duquan Graham, and reflected Ebon Moore’s determination that there is no underinsured exposure and that the claim would be closed, with an invitation to provide additional information if available.

Case: Julmonzhae-Moore-MVA-8-29-2023. Client: Julmonzhae Moore.

This note chronicles the claim communications surrounding the August 29, 2023 motor vehicle accident, involving four claimants and the insurance policy administered by Liberty Mutual. The policy is underwritten by Liberty Mutual Personal Insurance Company, with liability limits of $25,000 per person and $50,000 per occurrence. The insured is Dewayne Ward. The four claimants referenced in the communications are Julmonzhae Moore (Whaley Law Firm), Daquan Graham (Stout & Heuke), Naomi Robinson (Kanter & Pintaluga), and Ashlee Williams (as identified in the exchanges). The claim number assigned is 054658453-01, with an exposure number of 01.

The first relevant communications in this chain occurred on November 10, 2023. Robert Elliott of Liberty Mutual sent an email to Stout & Heuke (attorney Scott), Jessa Galosmo (Whaley Law Firm), and L. Graham (kpattorney.com) regarding the case. In the email, Elliott explained that four parties are making injury claims stemming from the 8/29/2023 auto accident, and that Liberty Mutual would need medical bills and records for all claimants in order to determine how the available limits of $25,000 per person / $50,000 per occurrence should be distributed. He noted that the insurer had informed all representatives for the injured parties of the available limits and the need for bills and records, and he invited the recipients to contact him with any questions. The message closed with Elliott’s signature block, including his phone number, and a note that the policy is underwritten by Liberty Mutual Personal Insurance Company, with the standard corporate footer.

In the same November 10, 2023 exchange, Elliott’s message was part of a broader thread that listed the three firms representing the other claimants: Stout & Heuke for Daquan Graham; Whaley Law Firm for Julmonzhae Moore; and Kanter & Pintaluga for Naomi Robinson. Elliott requested the forwarding of medical bills and records for all claimants and asked whether he could review the claimants’ PIP file documents. The email concluded with a formal closing from Elliott and the Whaley Law Firm contact information.

Subsequent messages in December continued to address the same issue of limits and documentation. On December 18, 2023, Elliott wrote that Liberty Mutual had received the time-limit demand package dated December 15, 2023 and was requesting an open extension to the demand due to the number of claimants relative to the available liability limits. He noted that, as of November 10, 2023, Liberty Mutual had informed the office of the potential insufficiency of limits given the number of claimants and reported that medical documentation had not yet been received for the remaining claimants Ashlee Williams, Naomi Robinson, and Daquan Graham. He asked for a prompt response.

On December 19, 2023, at 12:16 PM, Jessa Galosmo replied to Elliott, indicating a desire to resolve the matter before the holiday. Elliott followed up later that day, at 12:28 PM, reiterating that Liberty Mutual had received the time-limit demand package dated 12/15/2023 and stating that they were seeking the open extension due to multiple claimants and the limits of $25,000 per person / $50,000 per occurrence. He asked whether medical documentation for all claimants had been obtained and whether his office had been in contact with the other claimants’ attorneys to determine their progress in gathering medical records.

The thread continued on December 26, 2023, with Elliott stating that Liberty Mutual could neither reject nor accept the demand dated December 15, 2023 at that time, given there are four injured parties. He explained that bills and records for all parties were needed to determine how the available limits would be distributed and noted that Liberty Mutual had advised all representatives of the available limits and the need for bills and records. He urged contact for any questions or concerns.

On December 27, 2023, Jessa Galosmo forwarded Elliott’s December 26, 2023 message to Julmonzhae Moore and to the filevine app address associated with the case, carrying the subject line “Fwd: Claim#:054658453-01 / Julmonzhae Moore.” The forwarded message reiterated the same point: with four claimants, the available limits are $25,000 per person and $50,000 per occurrence, and the parties must provide medical bills and records for all claimants to determine the distribution of the available limits. The forwarded note indicated the policy is underwritten by Liberty Mutual Personal Insurance Company, included the standard corporate footer, and ended with Jessa’s customary sign-off and contact information for Whaley Law Firm (Ph: 502-357-9975; Fax: 502-364-9363).

In sum, the case involves four injury claims arising from the 8/29/2023 accident, with Liberty Mutual acknowledging the four claimants and the policy limits of $25,000 per person / $50,000 per occurrence. The insurers require medical bills and records for all claimants to determine how the limited liability coverage should be allocated and have repeatedly asked for documentation, while also seeking permission to review PIP files and coordinating with the claimant attorneys. The most recent communications in December 2023 show Liberty Mutual unable to accept or reject the December 15, 2023 demand until such documentation is provided, and they emphasized the need to resolve the matter before proceeding.

In January 2024, Liberty Mutual Personal Insurance Company, the insurer handling the case, sent a message to Jessa Galosmo at Whaley Law Firm (and copied others). The message stated that Liberty Mutual had received bodily injury demands for Ashlee Williams and Julmonzhae Moore, and that the company appeared to have sufficient information to globally tender the available bodily injury policy limits of $25,000 per person and $50,000 per occurrence to the four claimants: Daquan Graham, Naomi Robinson, Ashlee Williams, and Julmonzhae Moore. Liberty Mutual asked for the offices representing the claimants to come to an agreement on how the split of the $25,000 per person / $50,000 per occurrence would be allocated among the four claimants. The letter also indicated that, if needed, Liberty Mutual could appoint defense counsel and schedule a mediation. The message was signed by Robert Elliott and provided his contact number, 317-805-2841. The email carried metadata identifying the Claim-Number as 054658453, the Exposure-Number as 01, the Category as Manual Outbound E-Mail, the Description as undefined, and the Template-Id as BIFREEFORM. The policy is underwritten by Liberty Mutual Personal Insurance Company, with the company address listed as 175 Berkeley Street, Boston, MA 02116, and the copyright note for 2024 Liberty Mutual Insurance Company.

On January 23, 2024, at 9:39 a.m. (noted as 9:39?AM on the forwarded record), Robert Elliott sent a follow-up email to Jessa Galosmo, stating that Liberty Mutual had not yet received a response to the 1/11/2024 email and asking whether the Whaley firm had been in contact with the representatives for the other claimants involved in the 8/29/2023 auto accident. The email was addressed to Jessa Galosmo and referenced the same claim file (Claim#: 054658453-01 / Ashlee Williams, Julmonzhae Moore). The follow-up included Elliott’s request for coordination regarding the other claimants.

The chain of correspondence includes the initial 1/11/2024 message from Robert Elliott to Jessa Galosmo, scott@stoutheukelaw.com, and lgraham@kpattorney.com. In that message, Elliott stated that Liberty Mutual had received bodily injury demands for Ashlee Williams and Julmonzhae Moore and that there was sufficient information to globally tender the policy limits of $25,000 per person and $50,000 per occurrence to the four claimants (Daquan Graham, Naomi Robinson, Ashlee Williams, Julmonzhae Moore). He requested that the offices of the involved attorneys reach an agreement on how to divide the available limits among the four claimants and noted that Liberty Mutual could appoint defense counsel and schedule mediation if needed. The message concluded with Elliott’s signature, “Sincerely, Robert Elliott, 317-805-2841.”

The forwarding attorney, Jessa Galosmo, closed the thread with her note to Atty. Whaley on January 23, 2024 at 11:33:40 a.m., asking, “Hi Atty. Whaley, How should I respond here?” The thread also includes the standard closing line from Jessa: “All the best, Jessa Galosmo, Whaley Law Firm,” followed by her firm’s contact details: Ph: (502)357-9975, Fax: (502)364-9363.

Case: Julmonzhae-Moore-MVA-8-29-2023. Client: Julmonzhae Moore.

Re: Claim#: 054658453-01 / Daquan Graham, Naomi Robinson, Ashlee Williams, Julmonzhae Moore.

On January 23, 2024, a chain of emails began between Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm and colleagues at Stout & Heukelaw, with copies to Lexi Graham and the clients. In a message sent at 11:10 a.m., Aaron Whaley wrote: “I hope this email finds you well. Liberty Mutual tendered their $50,000 limits to be divided between the above four people. I represent Ashlee Williams and Julmonzhae Moore. I suggest we apportion using medical bills. Any objections?” He signed his message with his contact information and the firm’s address in Louisville, Kentucky.

Lexi Graham replied later that day at 11:16 a.m., cc’ing the handling attorney James Kamensky: “Hello Aaron, I have cc’d the handling attorney James on this email.” Her signature block listed multiple firm addresses across several states and included a standard attorney–client privilege notice.

At approximately 12:08 p.m. (the record shows “12:08?PM” in the forwarding line), James Kamensky, Esq. responded: “We are currently gathering medicals bills on Robinson, but generally we are good with apportionment based on medical bills. Will advise once we have them.” His sign-off included the firm’s name and several office locations, along with a standard copyright-like disclaimer.

Earlier in the thread, Aaron Whaley’s initial message to the group established the context: Liberty Mutual had tendered $50,000 to be divided among the four parties—Daquan Graham, Naomi Robinson, Ashlee Williams, and Julmonzhae Moore—and Aaron stated that he represents Ashlee Williams and Julmonzhae Moore and proposed apportioning the settlement based on medical bills, seeking any objections.

In a subsequent email dated January 31, 2024 at 12:34:47 p.m. Eastern Time, Aaron Whaley returned to the group and asked: “Could you all forward the amount of bills that you each have for your clients? I have the following; Ashlee Williams: $35,454.24; Julmonzhae Moore: $29,092.40.” This message circulated with the same chain of recipients and includes the same professional disclaimers and signatures present in the prior exchanges.

The email threads also included the standard attorney–client and work-product privileged notices, stating that the message and any attachments are confidential and should be deleted if the recipient is not the intended recipient.

Signature blocks in the messages show the following details. Aaron Whaley’s messages carried his contact information and office addresses: Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with a secondary listing in Louisville and an additional address in Boca Raton, FL, including a general phone number of (800) 586-5555 and a request that recipients consult the firm’s website or email for further contact. The messages also included a duplicate signature block with his name, title, and contact details.

Lexi Graham’s signature block listed multiple offices: 7733 Forsyth Blvd., Room 1100, Clayton, MO 63105; 10 S. Riverside Plaza, Ste 875, Chicago, IL 60606; 1615 Poydras Street, Ste 900, New Orleans, LA 70112; 250 E Wisconsin Ave., 18th Floor, Milwaukee, WI 53202; with a mail address at 925 S. Federal Hwy, 6th Floor, Boca Raton, FL 33432, a direct phone line, a fax number, and a website link, along with the same privilege notice.

Overall, the record documents: (1) the case reference Julmonzhae-Moore-MVA-8-29-2023 and the four claimants named in Claim#: 054658453-01; (2) Liberty Mutual’s $50,000 policy limits tendered to be divided among Daquan Graham, Naomi Robinson, Ashlee Williams, and Julmonzhae Moore; (3) Aaron Whaley’s representation of Ashlee Williams and Julmonzhae Moore and his proposal to apportion the settlement based on medical bills, with no objections noted at that time; (4) ongoing efforts to gather medical bills for Naomi Robinson; and (5) the specific bill amounts currently identified by Aaron Whaley for his clients: Ashlee Williams—$35,454.24 and Julmonzhae Moore—$29,092.40.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Julmonzhae-Moore-MVA-8-29-2023. Client: Julmonzhae Moore. This matter concerns Claim 054658453-01 involving Daquan Graham, Naomi Robinson, Ashlee Williams, and Julmonzhae Moore. The following communications occurred among counsel: Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm, representing Ashlee Williams and Julmonzhae Moore, with Scott Stout of Stout & Heuke Law Office, and others including James Kamensky, Lexi Graham, and the claimants.

On January 23, 2024, Aaron Whaley emailed to propose how to divide Liberty Mutual’s tendered limit of $50,000 among the four people named in the claim. He stated that he represents Ashlee Williams and Julmonzhae Moore and suggested apportioning the settlement using medical bills, asking if anyone had objections. Lexi Graham replied, cc’ing James Kamensky, indicating she had included the handling attorney on the thread. James Kamensky subsequently noted that they were currently gathering medical bills for Naomi Robinson and that, generally, they were comfortable with apportionment based on medical bills, and he would advise once they had them.

In a follow-up communication on January 31, 2024, Aaron Whaley requested that each side forward the amount of medical bills they had for their respective clients. He reported that Ashlee Williams’ total medical bills were $35,454.24 and Julmonzhae Moore’s were $29,092.40.

By February 8, 2024, Scott Stout advised that they were gathering bills and records for Daquan Graham as well, and that he did not have a problem dividing the recovery based on medical bills. Then, on February 12, 2024, Stout stated that Daquan Graham’s medical bills totaled $7,195.00.

Most recently, on March 1, 2024, Aaron Whaley followed up to confirm that the last of the medical bills were being collected and to determine whether the only remaining bills were those for Naomi Robinson, with the aim of moving toward resolution of the case.
episodes.author: Aaron Whaley

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Julmonzhae-Moore-MVA-8-29-2023
Client: Julmonzhae Moore

This file documents a series of communications concerning Julmonzhae Moore in relation to the motor vehicle accident case dated 8-29-2023. On November 29, 2023, Lisa Rivera, a Claim Resolution Specialist NF II with USRM Medical Claims, sent an email to Jessa Galosmo at Whaley Law Firm (and copied other firm recipients) with the subject “21d724fc-8d27-4da5-9107-7394e10b2d1c.pdf Julmonzhae Moore 054658453-03.” The message attached the current PIP log and Health Care Lien and asked for updates on three points: “Any new update on you direction to pay?,” “Is your client still treating?,” and “Do you want the HealthCare lien paid?” The email also requested an update and thanked the recipient. Rivera provided full contact and mailing information for Liberty Mutual/Safeco claims, including both USPS and FedEx/UPS addresses, direct dial number (856-355-7644), toll-free number (800-2Claims), and a fax number (888-268-8840). The message also listed the Medical Provider Billing Support line (855-677-2891), the email (LibertyPCC@mitchell.com), and the submission address for bills (imaging@libertymutual.com or PO Box 5014 Scranton, PA 18505-5014). It included an online privacy note and a two-way text update option, inviting the recipient to opt in by emailing to receive claim updates via text and asking to include the claim number and best text-reach number.

A prior version of the same message appears to have been sent on December 1, 2023, with the identical attachments (the current PIP log and Health Care Lien) and identical requests for updates on payment direction, ongoing treatment status of the client, and whether to pay the lien. The USPS/FedEx contact details and the entire set of instructions about submitting bills, privacy policy, and online claim management were included as in the November 29 email.

An earlier instance of this correspondence is shown from January 9, 2024, again repeating that the attached documents were the current PIP log and Health Care Lien and reiterating the same questions: “Any new update on you direction to pay?,” “Is your client still treating?,” and “Do you want the HealthCare lien paid?” along with the same mailing addresses, contact numbers, and online resources.

On March 5, 2024, at 16:47 local time, Jessa Galosmo replied to a forwarding chain directed to Greg Whaley, Justin Chumbley, and Bryce Koon with the note: “Let me know if I’ll send direction of payment.” The message then includes a forwarded thread beginning with Lisa Rivera’s communications (the November 29, 2023, December 1, 2023, and January 9, 2024 messages) asking for updates on payment direction, the client’s treatment status, and whether the Healthcare lien should be paid, all with the same attachments and details described above. The forwarded emails reiterate that the attachments are the current PIP log and Health Care Lien and repeat the same contact information and instructions for claim processing and privacy. The chain ends with Jessa’s sign-off from Whaley Law Firm, including her phone and fax numbers.

Sign-off: All the best, Jessa Galosmo Whaley Law Firm Ph: (502)357-9975 Fax: (502)364-9363
episodes.author: Jessa

On March 21, 2024 at 08:21:53 AM in the -0400 time zone, Jessa Galosmo forwarded an email to Greg Whaley concerning a new voice message left by Liberty Mutual for the BI adjuster on the Julmonzhae Moore and Ashlee Williams claim. The forward concerns the voicemail from Liberty Mutual identified as from (317) 805-2841, which was left on March 20, 2024 at 3:23 PM and pertains to the August 29th, 2023 auto accident.

The original message, generated via RingCentral, was received at 3:23 PM on Wednesday, March 20, 2024 and was addressed to Jessa Galosmo at the telephone number (502) 357-9975. The voicemail lasts 1 minute and 10 seconds. In the preview, the caller identifies himself as Robert Elliot with SAFE cos and states he is returning the message regarding the august 29th 2023 auto accident. He says that the limits have been tendered to all parties globally and that they are waiting on the attorney's offices to determine the distribution amounts for each party. He adds that he was under the assumption that Jessa’s office and the other two offices were working together to figure this out, and notes that the emails have already been sent from Liberty Mutual. He further says that if an update is sought on Naomi Robinson, one should contact Naomi Robinson's attorney at 317-805-2841, and he cites our file number 054. The message ends with an indication to listen to the full message via RingCentral, and to manage voicemails through the RingCentral account. The note also records that this is the voicemail left for the BI adjuster for the Julmonzae Moore and Ashlee Williams claim.

episodes.natural_language:
This narrative concerns the Julmonzhae Moore motor vehicle accident case, identified as Julmonzhae-Moore-MVA-8-29-2023, for client Julmonzhae Moore.

On Monday, June 24, 2024, at 3:15 PM Eastern Time, Jessa Galosmo of Whaley Law Firm sent an email to Aaron Whaley and Bryce Koon. She reported that the client had called again that day seeking an update. Jessa explained that one party is still waiting for medical records and bills so the settlement can be divided, and the client is frustrated and wants to speak directly with the lawyer.

In the prior thread, on Friday, June 14, 2024, at 11:37 AM (the time appears as 11:37?AM in the record), Aaron Whaley wrote: “Still waiting on one party to produce medical records and bills so we can divide up the settlement.”

Earlier, on Thursday, June 13, 2024, at 4:08 PM (time noted as 4:08?PM), Jessa Galosmo wrote: “Hi Atty.Whaley, Just wanted to know what's the update on the negotiation for Julmonzhae Moore and Ashlee Williams. I tried calling the adjuster, only got voicemail.” This message was part of the Whaley Law Firm correspondence, with Jessa’s signature block listing Whaley Law Firm, Ph: (502) 357-9975, Fax: (502) 364-9363.

The chain also includes the signatures associated with the messages: Aaron Whaley’s signature shows Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222, with phone 502-583-4022; and Jessa Galosmo’s signature again lists Whaley Law Firm with the same contact numbers.

The matter is insured under Liberty Mutual Personal Insurance Company, with Liberty Mutual’s address at 175 Berkeley Street, Boston, MA 02116.

The communications began with a forwarded thread involving Jessa Galosmo of Whaley Law Firm and attorney Greg Whaley, concerning an update on the claim and how the settlement amounts should be split among multiple claimants. The forward shows the message chain originated from Jessa Galosmo to Greg Whaley, asking: “Hi Atty. Whaley, Julmonzhae Moore is asking for an update. Have you spoken with the offices of the other claimants about how to split the amounts?” The forwarding includes the context that this is in reference to Claim Number 054658453-02.

We are waiting on your office, and the offices for the other claimants, to advise of the split. Please let me know the split amounts and I will send out releases to all parties. The emails collectively indicate a status update request and a request for the next steps in the process, tied to the 054658453-02 claim for Julmonzhae Moore. A courtesy copy has also been sent to State Farm who will likely provide representation for the Defendants in this claim. Once Service has taken place, the Defendants Attorney will have 30 days to file an Answer and initiate the Discovery Phase of Litigation. Once Discovery begins, we will reach out with additional details. Please do not hesitate to contact us directly with any questions you may have. -Sarena, The Whaley Law Firm

Case: Julmonzhae-Moore-MVA-8-29-2023
Client: Julmonzhae Moore

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Sent Client Update:

Good afternoon Julmonzhae,
We just wanted to update you that your claim has been filed with the Floyd Co. Indiana Circuit Court and we are awaiting the Defendants to be served. A courtesy copy has also been sent to State Farm who will likely provide representation for the Defendants in this claim. Once Service has taken place, the Defendants Attorney will have 30 days to file an Answer and initiate the Discovery Phase of Litigation. Once Discovery begins, we will reach out with additional details. Please do not hesitate to contact us directly with any questions you may have. -Sarena, The Whaley Law Firm 
__Person Making Contact:__ Sarena
__Date & Time__: January 29 2025
episodes.natural_language: Initial client contact on January 29, 2025 by Sarena of The Whaley Law Firm regarding the Julmonzhae Moore motor vehicle accident case (Julmonzhae-Moore-MVA-8-29-2023). A client update was sent to Julmonzhae Moore informing her that her claim has been filed with the Floyd Co. Indiana Circuit Court and that we are awaiting the Defendants to be served. A courtesy copy has also been sent to State Farm, which will likely provide representation for the Defendants in this claim. Once service has taken place, the Defendant's attorney will have 30 days to file an Answer and initiate the Discovery Phase of Litigation. Once Discovery begins, we will reach out with additional details. Please do not hesitate to contact us directly with any questions you may have. -Sarena, The Whaley Law Firm

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Julmonzhae-Moore-MVA-8-29-2023. Client: Julmonzhae Moore. This matter concerns Williams, Ward, Moore v. Robinson (Floyd County, case number Floyd 22D03-2501-CT-000157).

On May 5, 2025, at 12:25 PM, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email regarding the Williams, Ward, Moore v. Robinson case. The message was addressed to Dennis Cantrell and Zachary Reichle, with copies to Sarena Tuttle and the three Filevine project email addresses for Ashlee Williams (MVA 8/29/23), Dewayne Ward (MVA 8/29/23), and Julmonzhae Moore (MVA 8/29/23), as well as Janet Weile. The subject of the email was Williams, Ward, Moore v. Robinson (Floyd 22D03-2501-CT-000157). In the body, Koon advised that Plaintiffs’ First Set of Discovery, along with the associated notice filed that day, was attached, and that a Word copy was included for convenience. He invited any questions and provided his contact details, including The Whaley Law Firm’s address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, phone number (502) 365-5043, and fax number (502) 237-3207. The message bore the standard confidentiality notice typical of the firm: it stated that the electronic message was intended only for the named recipient and could contain attorney-client privileged or otherwise protected information; if received in error, the recipient was instructed to contact The Whaley Law Firm and advised that there was no waiver of privilege and that the information should not be used or forwarded to anyone not intended to receive it. The message also contained an image placeholder noting that an image had been removed by the sender.

In a subsequent exchange on May 19, 2025, at approximately 10:08 AM, Zachary Reichle of Stoll Keenon Ogden LLP wrote to counsel requesting a thirty-day extension to finalize Defendant’s responses to Plaintiffs’ discovery requests. He noted that the current due date was June 4 and explained that with an additional thirty days the due date would be July 7. He clarified that June 4 plus thirty days would land on July 4, which was a weekend, and that the two following days were the weekend, thus the July 7 date. The message closed with thanks and Reichle’s contact information: Direct line 317.224.2473; firm address at 334 N Senate Ave, Indianapolis, IN 46204; and additional firm locations in Louisville, Lexington, Indianapolis, Evansville, Frankfort, and Jeffersonville. The email carried SKO’s confidentiality notice, which stated that the message was for the sole use of the recipient(s) and may contain confidential and privileged information, with prohibitions on unauthorized review, use, or disclosure and instructions to contact the sender and destroy copies if the recipient was not the intended one.

Later on May 19, 2025, at 1:43:26 PM (GMT-04:00), Bryce Koon responded to counsel with a reply stating that July 7th was fine with him and that if there was anything else needed, they should let him know. This message included Koon’s confirmation and his standard signature block, reiterating his firm’s contact information and location, as well as a confidentiality notice affirming the intended recipient and the privileged nature of the content, along with instructions if the message was received in error.

Throughout these communications, the parties maintained standard confidentiality and privilege language typical of attorney correspondence, and the emails referenced the attached discovery documents and the request for a discovery-response extension.

Case: Julmonzhae-Moore-MVA-8-29-2023
Client: Julmonzhae Moore

In the matter titled Willaims, Ward & Moore v. Robinson, counsel at The Whaley Law Firm was copied on an April–June 2025 discovery exchange concerning the plaintiff Julmonzhae Moore, among others. On June 9, 2025, Lesly Torres, a paralegal, sent counsel copies of the discovery requests that had been served in the above-referenced matter, in both Word and PDF formats. The requests included six items: (1) Defendant Naomi Robinson’s First Request for Production of Documents to Plaintiff Ashlee Williams; (2) Defendant Naomi Robinson’s First Set of Interrogatories to Plaintiff Ashlee Williams; (3) Defendant Naomi Robinson’s First Request for Production of Documents to Plaintiff Julmonzhae Moore; (4) Defendant Naomi Robinson’s First Set of Interrogatories to Plaintiff Julmonzhae Moore; (5) Defendant Naomi Robinson’s First Request for Production of Documents to Plaintiff Dewayne Ward; and (6) Defendant Naomi Robinson’s First Set of Interrogatories to Plaintiff Dewayne Ward. The message indicated that these requests were served today in the referenced matter. The communication was directed to bryce@whaleylawfirm.com, with copies to Zachary Reichle of Stoll Keenon Ogden PLLC and Janet Weile, among others, and signaled that the email was from Indianapolis. Lesly Torres provided direct contact at 317.61.4224.

On July 15, 2025, Zachary Reichle, an Associate at Stoll Keenon Ogden PLLC, followed up with counsel regarding the status of Plaintiffs’ responses to Defendant’s discovery requests. He noted that the responses were originally due July 9, but that no responses had been received and no extensions of time had been requested. His message included his direct line (317.224.2473) and firm contact information, and carried the firm’s confidentiality notice.

Then, on July 28, 2025, a forwarded email from Bryce Koon at The Whaley Law Firm notified counsel that Plaintiffs’ Discovery Responses had been attached, and it provided a Dropbox link for the document production: https://www.dropbox.com/scl/fo/f27jsukejdzuxesqz496o/AOngUDwjYgN8Y2nRHEIpqrU?rlkey=fje64jsp5o4uw5m4tasky5vw7&st=q3oemih1&dl=0. In the forwarded message, Koon stated, “Good morning counsel, Attached please find Plaintiffs' Discovery Responses. Below you will find a Dropbox link to the document production in this regard.” The email was sent to Zachary Reichle, with copies to Lesly Torres, Dennis Cantrell (Dennis.Cantrell@skofirm.com), and Janet Weile. The Whaley Law Firm signature block followed, listing 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, phone 502-365-5043, and fax 502-237-3207, and included the firm’s confidentiality notice. The forwarded message also contained the prior June 9, 2025 email from Lesly Torres (as described above), which had stated that the six discovery requests had been served and included the same six items listed in June.

For completeness, the June 9, 2025 communication from Lesly Torres to Bryce Koon (cc’d to Zachary Reichle, Dennis Cantrell, and Janet Weile) summarized that the following discovery requests were served that day in the Williams, Ward & Moore v. Robinson matter: (1) Naomi Robinson’s First Request for Production of Documents to Ashlee Williams; (2) Naomi Robinson’s First Set of Interrogatories to Ashlee Williams; (3) Naomi Robinson’s First Request for Production of Documents to Julmonzhae Moore; (4) Naomi Robinson’s First Set of Interrogatories to Julmonzhae Moore; (5) Naomi Robinson’s First Request for Production of Documents to Dewayne Ward; and (6) Naomi Robinson’s First Set of Interrogatories to Dewayne Ward. The message invited any questions and was signed by Lesly Torres, Paralegal, with direct contact details and the Indianapolis location.

The case at hand is Williams, Ward, Moore v. Robinson (Floyd County case number 22D03-2501-CT-000157), with the focus file listed as Julmonzhae-Moore-MVA-8-29-2023 for client Julmonzhae Moore. The plaintiffs are Ashlee Williams, Dewayne Ward, and Julmonzhae Moore, each noted with an MVA date of 8/29/23. The correspondence involves counsel from The Whaley Law Firm and Stoll Keenon Ogden PLLC, and the communications were circulated among Bryce Koon, Esq. (The Whaley Law Firm), Zachary Reichle, Esq. (Stoll Keenon Ogden PLLC), with copies to Dennis Cantrell, Ashlee Williams MVA 8/29/23—Filevine Project Email Address, Dewayne Ward MVA 8/29/2023—Filevine Project Email Address, Julmonzhae Moore MVA 8/29/2023—Filevine Project Email Address, and Janet Weile.

In May 2025, the matter progressed through discovery and scheduling discussions. On May 5, 2025, Bryce Koon emailed counsel with the subject Williams, Ward, Moore v. Robinson (Floyd 22D03-2501-CT-000157), attaching Plaintiffs’ First Set of Discovery along with the associated notice filed that day. He noted that a Word copy was included for convenience and invited any questions. The message carried the standard attorney-client confidentiality notice.

A follow-up exchange occurred on May 19, 2025. In a message dated May 19, 2025 at 1:43 PM, Bryce Koon replied, signaling that July 7th was acceptable for whatever had been requested and offering to provide any additional information as needed. He closed with his customary contact information for The Whaley Law Firm: 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with a phone number of (502) 365-5043 and a fax number of (502) 237-3207.

Earlier that same day, at 10:08 AM, Zachary Reichle sent a separate email asking for an extension of time to finalize Defendant’s responses to Plaintiffs’ discovery requests. He proposed adding thirty days to the current due date of June 4, noting that the new due date would be July 7, since July 4 fell on a weekend and the following two days were weekend days. He signed as an Associate of Stoll Keenon Ogden PLLC and provided his direct contact information: 317-224-2473. His message included the firm’s disclaimer about confidentiality and privilege. The email chain also identified the recipients and cc’d individuals, including Dennis Cantrell, Ashlee Williams MVA 8/29/23—Filevine Project Email Address, Dewayne Ward MVA 8/29/2023—Filevine Project Email Address, Julmonzhae Moore MVA 8/29/2023—Filevine Project Email Address, and Janet Weile.

Subsequently, Bryce Koon again communicated on May 19, 2025 with the subject line specific to the Williams, Ward, Moore v. Robinson matter. He reaffirmed that July 7th would be fine and invited any further needs. The email continued to carry the same firm details for The Whaley Law Firm and the same Louisville address and contact numbers.

The email thread also shows an earlier May 5, 2025 message from Bryce Koon, which transmitted Plaintiffs’ First Set of Discovery along with the notice, as mentioned above, and stated that a Word copy was included for convenience. This message again carried the confidentiality notice and established the initial discovery exchange.

Moving forward to October 2025, the parties resumed discussions about depositions and mediation. On October 17, 2025, Zachary Reichle, Associate at Stoll Keenon Ogden PLLC (the recipient in this thread), wrote to counsel to request the deposition availability of Plaintiffs in November or December. He also reminded that there is a mediation deadline of January 31, 2026, and noted that the parties had (at a prior Case Management Conference on July 29, 2025) agreed upon Larry Church as mediator. He proposed reaching out to Larry Church’s office to determine availability. Reichle explained that the firm’s calendar was booked through January and early February of the following year, so mediation would likely occur in late February or March. He observed that the Court would probably not be troubled by this timing given that trial was not set to occur until December 2026, but he wanted to provide advance notice. His message included his direct line at 317-224-2473 and the firm’s broader contact details, along with the confidentiality notice customary to such correspondence.

In response, on October 22, 2025, Bryce Koon, writing for The Whaley Law Firm, informed counsel that his clients were available for depositions on any date between November 3 and November 7 and asked that if any of those dates worked, they should be confirmed so arrangements could be scheduled. He reiterated the same contact information for the firm and included the standard attorney-client privilege disclaimer.

Throughout the thread, the correspondence indicates that the deposition scheduling, discovery responses, and mediation planning were being coordinated among the same set of principals: W. Bryce Koon, Esq., for the plaintiffs (The Whaley Law Firm), and Zachary Reichle, Esq., for the defense (Stoll Keenon Ogden PLLC), with multiple copies to involved individuals associated with the three plaintiffs in the MVA group and their Filevine project communications. The communications were conducted with formalities typical of civil practice, including attachments (discovery sets and Word copies), notices, proposed deposition windows, and mediation timing aligned with a Case Management Conference held in July 2025. The parties continue to coordinate around depositions in early November 2025 and a mediation window in early 2026, with the understanding that trial in this matter is not scheduled until December 2026. The Whaley Law Firm’s office remains at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, and the parties’ communications carry the standard confidentiality disclaimers.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Julmonzhae-Moore-MVA-8-29-2023. Client: Julmonzhae Moore. This matter concerns Williams, Ward, Moore v. Robinson (Floyd 22D03-2501-CT-000157). The email correspondence runs between The Whaley Law Firm and Skofirm, with copies to Dennis Cantrell, Ashlee Williams MVA, Dewayne Ward MVA, Julmonzhae Moore MVA, and Janet Weile. The dated thread begins in May 2025 and continues through October 2025, outlining deposition scheduling for the plaintiffs and a related mediation plan.

On May 19, 2025, Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, replied to Zachary Reichle, Esq., of Skofirm, with the message that July 7th was fine and that he would let Zach know if anything else was needed. The email was CC’d to Dennis Cantrell, Ashlee Williams MVA 8/29/23, Dewayne Ward MVA 8/29/23, Julmonzhae Moore MVA 8/29/23, and Janet Weile, and it carried a standard attorney-client privilege notice at the bottom.

On October 17, 2025, Zachary Reichle wrote to solicit Plaintiffs’ deposition availability in November or December. He noted a mediation deadline of January 31, 2026 and stated that the parties had agreed to Larry Church as mediator at the Case Management Conference held on July 29, 2025. He added that he anticipated late February or March for mediation due to booked schedules in January and early February, and he suggested this timeline should not pose an issue for the Court since trial was not set until December 2026.

In a reply dated October 22, 2025, Bryce Koon informed Zach that his clients were available for depositions on any date during November 3–7, 2025, and asked that, if any of those dates would work, they could be scheduled accordingly.

On October 24, 2025, Zach Reichle responded that November 6 and 7 would work for their office. He proposed scheduling all three depositions consecutively, from 9:00 a.m. to noon on November 7, 2025, but he also stated there would be no issue with holding the depositions on separate days if necessary.

Later, on October 29, 2025 at 1:43 p.m., Bryce Koon replied that he had confirmed with Ms. Moore and Ms. Williams that they were available on November 7. He noted that Ms. Moore works that afternoon, so he preferred starting with her deposition first. He added that Mr. Ward had advised he would inform them by tomorrow whether he would be available on November 7, and he promised to relay any updates as soon as he received them.

Shortly thereafter, on October 29, 2025 at approximately 1:49 p.m., Zach Reichle replied that they would issue notices for Ms. Moore’s deposition beginning at 9:00 a.m. on November 7, with Ms. Williams’s deposition to follow at 11:00 a.m. He also stated that Mr. Ward was available the week of November 10 if November 7 did not work for him.

There is a further entry dated October 29, 2025 at 01:53:29 GMT-04:00, showing Bryce’s prior message as: “Counsel, Thank you for that. I will let you know for sure in the next day or so.” This appears to correspond to the ongoing scheduling discussions and reflects the exchange of confirmations and pending confirmations.

The thread then includes earlier fragments from October 22 and October 24 messages recapped above, confirming the scheduling trajectory: the plaintiffs’ depositions were being planned for the early November window, with specific time slots arranged for November 7 (Moore at 9:00 a.m., Williams at 11:00 a.m.) and Ward’s potential availability in the week of November 10 if necessary.

In summary, the parties and their counsel were coordinating depositions for the Williams, Ward, Moore v. Robinson case, targeting November 7, 2025, with Ms. Moore and Ms. Williams confirmed for deposition at 9:00 a.m. and 11:00 a.m. respectively, and with Mr. Ward’s availability to be confirmed or shifted to the following week if needed. They also discussed scheduling all three depositions on November 7 or on adjacent days and aligning mediation planning with a January 31, 2026 deadline and the previously agreed mediator, Larry Church. This record ends with the latest communications confirming the November 7 deposition times and ongoing coordination, reflecting a continuous effort to finalize deposition scheduling amid other docket constraints.

Case: Julmonzhae-Moore-MVA-8-29-2023. Client: Julmonzhae Moore. In the matter of Williams, Ward, Moore v. Robinson (Floyd 22D03-2501-CT-000157), the record reflects ongoing deposition scheduling and discovery communications among counsel for the plaintiffs—Williams, Ward, and Moore—and defense counsel, with The Whaley Law Firm and Stoll Keenon Ogden PLLC identified in the exchanges. The plaintiffs’ MVA occurred on August 29, 2023, and Julmonzhae Moore is listed as a client in the case. The emails involve plaintiffs’ depositions and related scheduling, as well as a mediation timeline that extends into early 2026. Recipients include Bryce Koon of The Whaley Law Firm; Zachary Reichle and Janet Weile of Stoll Keenon Ogden PLLC; and cc’d individuals associated with the three MVA clients via Filevine project email addresses: Ashlee Williams MVA 8/29/23, Dewayne Ward MVA 8/29/2023, and Julmonzhae Moore MVA 8/29/2023. The messages consistently note standard confidentiality and privilege notices.

The first dated thread in the record begins with communications around May 2025. A May 5, 2025 message from Bryce Koon to Dennis Cantrell and Zachary Reichle (with the three MVA clients’ Filevine addresses and Janet Weile CC’d) concerns scheduling depositions and related discovery matters, though the portion of the message visible in the record is truncated. A follow-up on May 7 indicates Bryce responded that July 7 would be fine. On May 19, 2025, Zach Reichle proposed a further extension of thirty days to finalize Defendant’s responses to Plaintiffs’ discovery requests, moving the due date from June 4 to July 7 (noting that June 4 plus thirty days lands on July 4 and the following two days are a weekend). Bryce replied later on May 19 that July 7 would be fine and offered to assist with anything else needed.

Moving forward to late 2025, the parties' discussions turned to scheduling Plaintiffs’ depositions. On October 17, 2025, Zach Reichle wrote that the plaintiffs’ depositions should be scheduled and asked Bryce to provide availability in November or December. He also noted a mediation deadline of January 31, 2026 and stated that the parties had agreed, at a Case Management Conference held on July 29, 2025, to have Larry Church serve as mediator. He observed that January and early February were fully booked for his office, so mediation would likely occur in late February or March 2026, and he did not expect this to create issues with the Court given that trial was not set until December 2026. The message included Reichle’s contact details (Direct: 317.224.2473) and a standard confidentiality disclaimer.

On October 22, 2025, Bryce Koon replied that his clients were available for depositions on any date from November 3 through November 7. He asked to be advised which dates would work so scheduling could proceed, reiterating availability for the three plaintiffs.

On October 24, 2025, Zach Reichle responded that November 6th and 7th work for their office and asked whether all three depositions could be scheduled consecutively. He proposed a schedule of 9:00 a.m. to noon on November 7th for the depositions but stated that they were open to holding the depositions on separate days if necessary. The message also noted the option to proceed with all three depositions during the dates proposed and mentioned the possibility of arranging a stacked schedule if feasible.

On October 29, 2025, Bryce Koon replied that Ms. Moore and Ms. Williams were available on the 7th, and that Mr. Ward would inform by tomorrow whether he would be available on November 7th. He indicated he would notify the other side as soon as he received Ward’s confirmation.

Throughout these exchanges, the parties repeatedly referenced the case caption and the litigation timeline, including the pursuit of depositions for the three plaintiffs (Williams, Ward, and Moore) and the planned mediation with Larry Church, consistent with the July 29, 2025 Case Management Conference agreement. The notes also reflect that the email communications include confidentiality and privilege notices and identify the sending law firms and the relevant Filevine project email addresses for the participants.

Contact information appears in the record for the primary counsel: W. Bryce Koon, Esq., The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; Phone: 502-365-5043; Fax: 502-237-3207. Zachary Reichle, Associate at Stoll Keenon Ogden PLLC, is listed with direct line 317-224-2473. The records also show copies sent to Dennis Cantrell, Ashlee Williams MVA, Dewayne Ward MVA, Julmonzhae Moore MVA, and Janet Weile, with the three MVA clients’ Filevine project email addresses noted in the CC field.

In summary, the notes document a coordinated effort in spring 2025 and fall 2025 to schedule depositions for the three plaintiffs in the Williams-Ward-Moore v. Robinson case, with November 3–7, 2025 emerging as a primary window and a specific emphasis on November 7 for the round of depositions, alongside the ongoing plan for mediation to occur in early 2026, and a trial not anticipated until December 2026.

Case: Julmonzhae-Moore-MVA-8-29-2023. Client: Julmonzhae Moore. This note concerns the Moore/Williams Depositions.

In the correspondence dated November 13, 2025 at 5:27:05 PM (Eastern Time, GMT-05:00), W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, sent a message to Zachary Reichle, Associate at Stoll Keenon Ogden PLLC, with copies to several Filevine project email addresses (Ashlee Williams MVA 8/29/23, Julmonzhae Moore MVA 8/29/2023, and Dewayne Ward MVA 8/29/2023). The email stated: “Good evening counsel, Please provide me with dates for your client's deposition and we will get Dewayne's done the same day.” It was signed with Bryce Koon’s name and title, followed by The Whaley Law Firm’s contact information: 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; Phone: (502) 365-5043; Fax: (502) 237-3207. The message included a standard attorney-client privilege disclaimer advising that the electronic communication is intended only for the named recipient and that any inadvertent receipt should be reported to the firm, with directions not to use or forward the information to unauthorized persons.

Earlier, on November 6, 2025, there was an exchange between Zachary Reichle and Bryce Koon regarding the deposition logistics. At 12:10 PM, Reichle forwarded an update to Bryce Koon and Dennis Cantrell, stating that the reporter had confirmed the depositions would proceed as scheduled and that they were awaiting a calendar invite with the Zoom link, which they would forward when available. Reichle also provided a Zoom meeting link for the deposition along with dial-in information: Join Zoom Meeting at https://stewartrichardson.zoom.us/j/81627086306?pwd=beXeD9HWwYbPQ9aVXcVoZd4CnKxuFN.1, Dial-in number 1 312 626 6799, Meeting ID 816 2708 6306, Passcode 462204. Reichle signed as Associate, with the direct line 317.224.2473, and listed the firm’s address as Stoll Keenon Ogden PLLC, 334 N Senate Ave, Indianapolis, IN 46204. The message included a confidentiality notice typical of the firm’s communications.

Earlier still, on November 6, 2025 at 11:54 AM, Bryce Koon replied to Reichle and Dennis Cantrell, asking: “Good morning counsel, Do you happen to have the Zoom link for tomorrow's depos? Just want to make sure I have everything ready to go with my clients.” He provided his contact details and The Whaley Law Firm’s address and phone and fax numbers, followed by an image placeholder note and the standard confidentiality disclaimer.

Together, these messages comprise the deposition coordination for Moore and Williams, with the latest instruction on November 13, 2025 to provide deposition dates for the Moore client and schedule Dewayne Ward’s deposition on the same day, and with Zoom logistics shared in the November 6, 2025 exchanges.
